coredata.dc:title: Theoretical calculations on the structure of the hexahydrated divalent zinc, cadmium and mercury ions
coredata.dc:creator: Strömberg, Dan
Sandström, Magnus
Wahlgren, Ulf
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
SCF calculations have been performed on the title compounds in order to study the possible reasons for the anomalously large spread in the mean HgO bond distance previously obtained for hydrate mercury (II) ions in solution. An energy minimum is found for all three complexes, [M(H2O)6]2+, M  Zn, Cd or Hg, for a regular Th ground-state nuclear configuration. The larger spread of the HgO distances can be explained in terms of a weak second-order Jahn—Teller effect. An enhanced vibronic coupling leads in the mercury case to larger vibrational amplitudes of the coupling mode without invoking a static distortion. The longer mean HgO distance found for the hydrated mercury (II) ion in solution than in a solid hexahydrate can be explained by assuming a larger asymmetry in the distribution of the HgO bonds. Calculations on the [Hg(H2S)6]2+ complex also show an energy minimum for the Th configuration, although in this case the adiabatic potential surface is very flat, and more refined methods of calculation could yield a distored ground-state configuration.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 172, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEnERS 24August 1990 Dan Stromberg Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Gothenburg, S-412 96 Goteborg. Sweden Magnus Sandstrom Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Royal Institute of Technology, S-10044 Stockholm, Sweden and Ulf Wahigren Institute of Physics, University of Stockholm, Vanadisvagen 9, S-11346 Stockholm, Sweden Received 26 February 1990; in final form 26 June 1990 SCF calculations have been performed on the tille compounds in order to study the possible reasons for the anomalously large spread in the mean Hg O bond distance previously obtained for hydrated mercury (II) ions in solution. An energy minimum is found for all three complexes, [M(H20)6 ~2+, M=Zn, Cd or Hg, for a regular Tb ground-state nuclear configuration. The larger spread of the fig O distances can be explained in terms of a weak second-order Jahn Teller effect. An enhanced vibronic coupling leads in the mercury case to larger vibrational amplitudes of the coupling mode without invoking a static distortion. The longer mean 14g C) distance found for the hydrated mercury (II) ion in solution than in a solid bexahydrate can be explained by asswn- ing a larger asymmetry in the distribution of the fig O bonds. Calculations on the [Hg(H25)6] 2+ complex also show an energy minimum for the Tb configuration, although in this case the adiabatic potential surface is very flat, and more refined methods of calculation could yield a distorted ground-state configuration. 1. Introduction In X-ray diffraction studies of the hydration in so- lution of the divalent ions of group 23, viz., Zn, Cd and Hg, an anomalously large spread was found of the mean Hg O bond length [1]. It was measured in terms of the Debye WaIler factor, exp ( 2 a2 k2), where a is the root mean square (nus) deviation from the mean distance assuming a symmetric Gaus- sian distribution, and the scattering variable is k= (4r/a)sin 9. The experimental a value may ac- commodate both vibrational amplitudes and small deviations from a regular structure [2]. It is well established that distorted octahedral con- figurations of the oxygen atoms are found around the metal ions in the hexahydrated copper(II) and chro- mium (II) complexes, while other divalent ions of similar size such as Ni(II) have a regular coordi- nation [3 5]. This observation is easily understood in terms of the first-order Jahn Teller effect [6]. In a regular Th complex the metal atom d orbitals are split into one group of three degenerate t2g orbitals, and another group at higher energy with two degen- erate e5 orbitals directed towards the ligand atoms. With a cl~ or a high spin d4 electron configuration, one of the two e5 orbitals will be singly occupied and the complex will distort as a consequence of the first- order Jahn Teller effect. The large distortions around the hydrated Cu2~ and Cr2~ ions give rise to two groups of distances in solution (Cu 4O~ 2.0; Cu 2O~ 2.3 A and Cr 40~ 2.0 2.1; Cr-2O~ 2.3 2.5 A), which are static on a diffraction or vibrational timescale [3,7,8]. An infrared spectroscopic study of the hydrogen bonds around hexahydrated Cu2~ 49 0009-2614/90/S 03.50 1990 Elsevier Science Publishers WV. (North-Holland) Theoretical calculations on the structure of the hexahydrated divalent zinc, cadmium and mercury ions Volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24August 1990 ions in solution, showed a separated band for the weakly coordinated axial water ligands, which is not found for Ni2~ 13], nor in a similar recent study on a Hg2~ solution [9]. However, the hexahydrated complexes of the di- valent Zn, Cd and Hg ions are all non-degenerate in the ground state, and if a distortion is the reason for the observed anomalies in the mercury case, it must have another origin and probably a different char- acter than for the corresponding hexahydrated di- valent Cu and Cr complexes. The present study was undertaken in an effort to elucidate the reason for the large a value found for the [Hg (H20 ) 612+ ion in solution. Structures with two short and four longer bonds are common for mercury (II) compounds [10,11], but recently a hexapyridine mercury(II) complex was found with two axial Hg N bonds longer (Art 0.08 A) than the other four [12]. If the average nuclear configuration of the com- plex in its ground state is regular, the ligands should be very mobile in solutions with small force con- stants in some vibrational modes. The symmetric metal ligand stretching vibrational frequencies have been measured by Raman spectroseopy (table 1) and show that the force constant for this mode is higher for the Hg complex than for the Cd, despite its longer bond length. A higher mobility of the aqua ligands (and also possible deviations from a regular coor- dination) should thus be associated with the asym- metric stretching vibrational mode. One mechanism which has the potential to explain both a distortion of a regular non-degenerate structure and a small force constant in some (asymmetric or symmetrie) vibrational mode, is the vibronic coupling in the sec- ond-order (or pseudo) Jahn Teller effect, SOJT [131. Following this theory, the destabilization of the ground state can be explained in terms of a vi- bronie interaction with a low-lying excited state [14]. The SOJT effect has been used to explain distorted nuclear configurations for many systems [14,15]. A distortion of a regular octahedral coordination by a tetragonal compression or elongation (Th +D2h) was thus considered in the calculations of this study. In order to compare the trends, calculations were carried out on the three species [Zn(H2O)6]2~, [Cd(H2O)6]2~ and [Hg(H2O)6]2~, and also on the complex [Hg(H2S )6]2+, which is expected to have a more covalent bond character and a greater ten- dency to distort than the hydrated ion because of the softer sulphur ligand [16]. No experimental data are available on this complex, however. We have previously investigated the first-order Jahn Teller distortions of [Cu (H20 )~ ]2+ and [Cr (H2O ) 612+ with quantum-chemical methods [1,17]. These investigations were carried out at the SCF level of approximation and yielded results in the expected directions although the magnitude of the calculated effects came out too small. It has also been shown in a previous study that the apparently irregular structures of the tellurites can in fact be ex- plained in terms of a SOJT effect [18]. 2. Computational details All the calculations presented in this work have been carried out at the SCF level of approximation, except for a few estimations of excitation energies by the CAS method. For the cadmium and mercury at- oms, and effective core potential (ECP) with a fro- zen outer core shell was used [19]. Relativistic ef- fects were included in the calculations by fitting the ECP parameters to orbital energies and shapes ob- tained from relativistic atomic calculations using the Sucher projection procedure [20] as implemented by Almlof et al. [21]. No account was taken of spin orbit effects or relativistic electron electron inter- actions. This procedure has been shown to give re- liable results in several previous applications [22,23]. ECP descriptions were also used for oxygen and sul- phur, and have previously been shown to give very accurate results in comparisons with all electron cal- culations [3,17,23]. The basis sets used for Zn was the SDZC basis sug- gested by Tatewaki and Huzinaga [24], augmented by two diffuse p functions describing the 4p atomic orbital and a polarizing d function. The basis set was thus fully contracted in the core region, doubly split for 4s and 4p and triply split for 3d. For cadmium and mercury a contracted basis set with 7s-, 6p- and Sd-type basis functions were used. The basis sets and the ECP parameters for cadmium and mercury are given in ref. [231, for oxygen in ref. [25] and sul- phur in ref. [26]. The hydrogen basis is the Huzi- naga 4s basis contracted to 2s with the exponents 50 volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEYrERS 24August 1990 scaled by a factor of 1.25 A [27]. The internal H20 and H2S geometries were fixed at the experimental values in the gas phase (O H 0.957 A, LHOH 104.5 and S H 1.3455 A, t HSH 93.3 , respec- tively) [28,29]. The point symmetry of the regular complexes is Th, see fig. 1. The symmetric-stretching vibrational mode was calculated by simultaneously moving all the atoms along the A5 symmetry coordinate. The lowest excited state for the complexes is in all cases of E5 symmetry, corresponding to a d to s atomic ex- citation, and the symmetry of the vibrational mode giving vibronic coupling of these states is conse- quently also of E8 type. This asymmetric normal Fig. 1~ The hexahydrated complex in Tb symmetry. mode was calculated using the symmetry coordinate &=I1(2arL +4Ar~). The theoretical estimates of the vibrational con- tributions to the a values were carried out by cal- culating the integral f ,~x2 p !P(x) 12 dx, where W(x) is the harmonic vibrational wave function, The ef- fects of higher vibrational excitations were incor- porated using a Boltzmann distribution for the oc- cupation of the excited states. It should be stressed that this can only partly explain the total rms devia- tion since only one vibrational mode was considered. 3. Results and discussion The experimental frequencies for the totally sym- metric A, stretching vibration are similar for all the complexes (table 1). Since the central atom is at rest for this vibrational mode, the force constants must also be similar. However, moving down the group the Coulombic contribution to the binding should decrease because of the increase in the bond dis- tances (table 1), and similarly, this should be re- flected by a steady decrease in the vibrational fre- quencies. Instead, an increase is found for the mercury complex. One possible interpretation of this observation is that the covalent character in the binding is more pronounced for the Hg O bonds than for Zn.-O or Cd-O. The calculated frequencies (table 2) for the sym- metric A5 vibrations are somewhat low compared to the experimental values, in particular for Hg. Low vibrational frequencies are expected for systems dis- sociating with correct charges, since corrections for correlation effects, not considered in the SCF theory, Table 1 Experimental data for the hexahydrated divalent Zn, Cd and Hg ions Complex iY(A,),,,~, a) (cm ) i(A,)cry~ ~ (cm ) (A) SH2yd, (kJmol ) r,01~,(M O) (A) r~ajM O) (A) Zn 386 385 0.071 b) 2063 2.10 b) 20926) Cd 352 352 0.05e) 1831 2.29 e) 2.277(2) Hg 370 360 0.102 1845 2.40, 2.341(6) a) Ramanspectra,ref. Il] (ref. (30]forZninaqueoussolution). b)Ref [31] (b=2u =O.OIOA?). ~Ref, 1321. C)) Ref. [33], mean X-ray value (neutron diffraction 2.096A). C) Ref. [34J. ~ Ref. [35], 2.28, A when corrected for thermal motion (riding motion). ) Ref. [il, b0.021 AZ. b) Ref [1]. Ref I3~l, 2.35 Awben eorrected forthermal motion. 51 Central atom Ligand 9(A,) (cm ) D(E,) (cm ) a,~ (A) r, (A) D, (kimol ) Exeit. energy b) (ev) Zn H24J 349 246 0.034 2.12 1540 12.5 Cd 1120 319 239 2.32 1318 11.7 Hg H,0 312 184 0.044 2.40 1272 7.2(7.5) e) Hg H2S 171 94 0.052 2.84 866 ( 6.2) ~ 24 August 1990 volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS Table 2 Calculated data for the hexasolvated complexes of divalent Zn, Cd and Hg in Tb symmetry rms contribution from the E, vibration, b) Calculated energy for the d to s excitation ( A1.- LE). c) Values within parentheses are obtained using CAS calculations. asymmetric E8 mode should thus be more important in the mercury system, an effect which will tend to destabilize the regular coordination in the ground state. The destabilization is not found to be strong enough actually to distort the complex, but it will certainly increase the vibrational amplitude for this mode. This is a typical case of a weak SOJT effect [14]. As can be seen in table 1, the experimentally de- termined metal oxygen distances and the peak fre- quencies of the broad Raman bands of the symmet- ric stretching A5 modes are similar in crystals and in solution for the hexahydrated Zn and Cd complexes. However, an apparent contradiction is found for the hexahydrated Hg complex, which has a higher fre- quency in solution than in the solid state. This gives a higher stretching force constant which would imply stronger bonds in solution, although the observed mean Hg O distance is longer than in the solid hy- drate. Similar trends in the bond lengths and vibra- tion frequencies are also found for the oxygen-co- ordinated dimethyl sulfoxide hexasolvates in solid and in solution [1,36], again accompanied by anomalously large a values for the DMSO-solvated mercury(II) ion in solution [1]. A possible explanation is that for the destabilized ground state of the mercury complex, the E,-type vi- bration in the non-rigid environment in solution has not only a large amplitude but also a high degree of anharmonicity, giving rise to a large asymmetry in the distribution of the Hg O distances. This would cause an apparent increase in the mean value ob- tained for the Hg O distances when a Gaussian dis- tribution is fitted to the data [2], without a corre- sponding decrease in the overall bond strength. As similar effects are found in the aprotie DMSO so- would make the potential well deeper. Considering the level of accuracy in the calculation, one must judge the results acceptable for Zn and Cd. It may be noted that the deviations from the experimental values for these two complexes are very similar, 31 and 33 cm , respectively. The error obtained for the Hg complex is larger, 58 cm , which is also con- sistent with a higher degree of covalency. This would cause larger correlation effects in the mercury case as compared to the other two systems, and a larger error would thus be expected at the SCF level. A comparison between the trends in the calculated binding energies D~ and the measured hydration en- thalpies AH~ (tables 1 and 2) supports this picture, although in this case the effects are less clear. Both quantities decrease when we go from Zn to Cd, but in the next step, i.e. going from Cd to Hg, the mea- sured hydration enthalpy increases somewhat, while there is still a slight decrease in the computed bind- ing energy. However, contributions to the experi- mental MI value from environmental effects, e.g. electrostatic and polarisation interactions with the surrounding solvent and the breaking and reforma- tion of hydrogen bonds, do not allow a detailed com- parison with the D8 energy. The frequency for the first normal mode of E5 symmetry is markedly lower for the Hg complex than for Zn and Cd, even if we assume that the error in the calculated frequency in the mercury case could be up to 30 cm larger than for Zn and Cd (cf, the discussion above). This difference between the com- plexes can be interpreted in terms of the SOJT effect. The calculated electronic excitation energy to the first F state, is markedly lower in the mercury complex (table 2) than in the other two systems. The vi- bronic coupling to the ground state involving the 52 Volume 172, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 24August 1990 lutions [I], the hydrogen bonds are evidently not an important factor for the anharmonicity. The bond distances in the crystal hydrates are slightly shorter than the calculated ones in all three cases (tables 1 and 2). The largest difference is found for mercury as would be expected from a larger cor- relation error. The observed a values include the integrated ef- fects of all the populated vibrational modes in the system, as well as contributions from other sources of distortion. To calculate all vibrational contribu- tions to the ruts deviations would be an overwhelm- ing undertaking. However, it seems reasonable to as- sume that the main characteristics of the difference between the complexes should be described by the Jahn Teller active asymmetric E,-mode considered here. We have thus calculated the contributions from the first four vibrational levels in E, symmetry at room temperature (assuming a Boltzmann distri- bution) for the Zn and Hg complexes. The calcu- lated rms deviations (a~ in table 2) are about a fac- tor of two smaller than the observed a values, which is not surprising since only one vibrational mode is considered in the calculations. lt may therefore be more illuminating to compare their ratios, The ratio of the calculated o~ values of the Hg and Zn com- plexes is 1.3, and the ratio of the corresponding ob- served a values is 1.44(15). It should be noted that a a~ ratio of 1.44 applied to the harmonic ~(E,) fre- quency of the zinc complex would correspond to about 171(18) cm for the mercury complex, while our theoretical (SCF) value is 184 cm . Based on the calculated and observed ratios, it seems reason- able to conclude that there is a substantial contri- bution from the SOJT effect to the a value in the mercury case. In particular, it is not necessary to as- sume a non-regular average distribution of the Hg O distances to explain the large experimental a val- ues in solution. Divalent mercury often forms, in contrast to zinc and cadmium, two short and strong bonds to sulphur ligands in the solid phase. In fact, no compound with six Hg S bond in a regular hexacoordination is known, although approximately tetrahedral four-co- ordination is common for all three ions [10,111. It is thus reasonable to assume that the ligand-induced tendency to distortion of an octahedral coordination is greater for the softer sulphur ligands than for those coordinating through the harder oxygen atom. Our calculations on the [Hg(H2S)6]2~ complex verify that this is indeed the case, although a regular hexacoordination still gives the lowest energy in our model. The calculated E, vibration is only 94 cm , however, and may well turn imaginary in a more refined calculation. The ratio between the calcu- lated o~ values for the [Hg(H2O)6J2~ and the [Hg(H2S)6]2~ complexes is 1.2, which would cor- respond to an increase in the ruts amplitude and give an experimental a value of least 0.15 A for the Hg S bonds. It is also possible that a hexasolvated com- plex would in fact distort to an average configuration with two short (or two long) opposite Hg S bonds. It should be noted that the vibrational frequencies calculated for the [Hg(H2S)6]24 complex (table 2) correspond to lower force constants than for the hy- drated complex due to the mass difference between H2S and H2O. The dissociation energy D8 is much smaller with hydrogen sulphide as the ligand than with water in the hexacoordinated complexes (table 2). This will also affect the stability relative to a tetrahedral co- ordination, and it is possible that the most stable configuration in solution would actually be the te- trasolvate, [Hg(H2S)4]2t. 4. Concluding remarks The results of the present study provide a strong indication that the hydrated mercury (H) ion has on the average a regular coordination in solution. The unusually large ruts deviations observed by X-ray diffraction methods for the Hg O bonds in solution can be explained in terms of the second-order Jahn Teller effect, i.e. a vibronie coupling mainly between a vibrational E,-type mode and an excited state with an open d orbital on the Hg-atom. The longer mean Hg O distances observed in solution than in solids can be explained by assuming a larger anharmon- icity. Several observed effects indicate that cova- lency becomes more important for the hydrated mer- cury complex than for the corresponding zinc and cadmium ions, and the present theoretical results are compatible with this interpretation. According to the calculations, a regular structure has the lowest energy also for the hexasolvate 53 Volume 172, number CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEITERS 24August 1990 [9] P..A. Bergstrom, J. Lindgren and M. The calculated vibrational frequency for the Ectype asymmetric vibrational mode is very low, however, only 94 cm in our model, and it is pos- sible that this configuration would not be the most stable in a more refined model or in a solution. Spin orbit interactions have not been discussed in the present study, and clearly the spin orbit effect contributes more or less to all of the observed phe- nomena. However, the observations considered in the present study can be interpreted without re- course to spin orbit effects, and in particular the sec- ond-order Jahn Teller effect can be used to explain most of the observed difference in the rms devia- tions of the Zn O and the Hg O bonds. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: SCF calculations have been performed on the title compounds in order to study the possible reasons for the anomalously large spread in the mean HgO bond distance previously obtained for hydrate mercury (II) ions in solution. An energy minimum is found for all three complexes, [M(H2O)6]2+, M  Zn, Cd or Hg, for a regular Th ground-state nuclear configuration. The larger spread of the HgO distances can be explained in terms of a weak second-order Jahn—Teller effect. An enhanced vibronic coupling leads in the mercury case to larger vibrational amplitudes of the coupling mode without invoking a static distortion. The longer mean HgO distance found for the hydrated mercury (II) ion in solution than in a solid hexahydrate can be explained by assuming a larger asymmetry in the distribution of the HgO bonds. Calculations on the [Hg(H2S)6]2+ complex also show an energy minimum for the Th configuration, although in this case the adiabatic potential surface is very flat, and more refined methods of calculation could yield a distored ground-state configuration.
